main: Heaven. Let a major sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen.
1: The dragon is submerged. Do not act.
2: You see a dragon in the field. It is favorable to see the great person.
3: The noble person works and works till the end of the day, and is vigilant in the evening.
Danger, no harm.
4: Perhaps the dragon is leaping in the pool. No harm.
5: The flying dragon is in the sky. It is favorable to see the great person.
6: The dragon flies too high. Regrets.
You see a host of headless dragons. Auspicious.

main: Earth. Let a major sacrifice be conducted. The omen of the mare is favorable.
The noble person proceeds with a purpose. You may at first be lost, but later gain a master.
Favorable. A friend will be gained in the southwest, a friend will be lost in the northeast.
The omen of peace is auspicious.
1: You are treading on frost: hard ice is coming.
2: Straight, square, and great: even without review, there is nothing that will not end favorably.
3: Maintain your integrity and you can engage in divination.
Perhaps you will undertake service to the king. Nonachievement will come to an end.
4: The sack has been drawn tight. Neither harm nor praise.
5: A yellow garment. A major auspicious omen.
6: Dragons battle in the field. Their blood flows black and yellow.
The omen of eternity is favorable.

main: Difficulties. Let a major sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen.
Do not proceed with a purpose. It is favorable to appoint feudal princes.
1: Stone pillars: a favorable omen for remaining at home.
It is favorable to appoint feudal princes.
2: You are stuck and blocked. Chariots and horses arrayed in teams.
Robbers and bandits seeking marriage.
The omen of the woman: she shall not now be wed. In ten years she shall be wed.
3: Those who hunt deer without vigilance merely stray into the depths of the forest.
The noble person possesses subtle understanding: it is preferable to abandon the hunt.
Going forth will bring misfortune.
4: Chariots and horses arrayed in teams.
In seeking marriage, it is auspicious to go forth. There is nothing that will not end favorably.
5: Save the fat of the hunted deer.
Auspicious omen for small matters, inauspicious omen for great matters.
6: Chariots and horses arrayed in teams. Tears and blood will flow.

main: Ignorance.
Let a sacrifice be conducted.
It was not I who sought the ignorant child.
It was the ignorant child who sought me.
When the divination was first conducted, I spoke. To ask twice and thrice shows disrespect.
When there is disrespect, I do not reveal a favorable omen.
1: Ignorance is exposed.
It is favorable to punish the prisoner and to remove his shackles, but going forth will bring misfortune.
2: It is auspicious to be tolerant with the ignorant.
It is auspicious to choose a wife for the son. The son can establish a household.
3: Do not choose the woman.
She sees the man and his gold, but she has lost herself.
There is no endeavor that will end favorably.
4: Ignorance is all around. Misfortune.
5: An ignorant child. Auspicious.
6: In dispelling ignorance, it is not favorable to act as an enemy.
It is favorable to ward off enemies.

main: Waiting. Trust and glory. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
The omen is auspicious. It is favorable to ford the great river.
1: You wait in the countryside.
It is favorable to act with constancy. No harm.
2: You wait in the sand. A small discussion. The end will be auspicious.
3: You wait in the mud. This causes enemies to come.
4: You wait in the presence of blood. You emerge from the cave.
5: You wait in the presence of food and wine. The omen is auspicious.
6: Entering into the cave there come three uninvited guests.
Respect them and the end will be auspicious.

main: A dispute. There is trust, yet there are obstructions. Be vigilant.
Midway all things are auspicious, but the end will bring ill fate.
It is favorable to see the great person.
It is not favorable to ford the great river.
1: It is not beneficial to persist in the affair. A small discussion.
The end will be auspicious.
2: Do not dispute. Return home! Flee!
The townspeople, three hundred households, commit no error.
3: Nourish ancient virtue. An omen of danger, but the end will be auspicious.
Perhaps you will undertake service to the king. No achievement.
4: Do not dispute. Approaching fate returns.
A change of heart. The omen of peace is auspicious.
5: A dispute. A major auspicious omen.
6: A leather belt which will perhaps be granted.
It will be stripped off thrice by the end of the morning.

main: The army. The omen of the powerful man is auspicious. No harm.
1: When the army marches forth apply discipline lest you amass ill fate.
2: Auspicious for those in the midst of the army. No harm.
The king thrice grants titles of rank.
3: Perhaps the army is carting corpses. Inauspicious.
4: The army makes its encampment on the left. No harm.
5: Fowl in the field. It is favorable to refrain from speaking. No harm.
The elder son commands the army, the younger son is carting corpses.
The omen is inauspicious.
6: The great prince follows his destiny. He founds a state and perpetuates the dynasty.
The lowly person must not act.

main: Standing together. Auspicious. The primal oracle: the fundamental and eternal omen.
No harm.
In coming from the place of strife, the later man will meet with ill fate.
1: If there is trust, stand together with him. No harm.
Trust is like a full earthen jar: when the end comes you will have enough. Auspicious.
2: Stand together with him inwardly. The omen is auspicious.
3: Those who stand together with him are bandits.
4: Stand together with him outwardly. The omen is auspicious.
5: Standing together is manifested.
The king drives out the game birds thrice. He loses the forward-running fowl.
The townspeople have not been admonished. Auspicious.
6: Those who stand together with him will lose their heads. Inauspicious.

main: A small offering of cattle. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
Thick clouds without rain, approaching from my western fields.
1: You return from a journey: how could there be harm in this? Auspicious.
2: You lead the return. Auspicious.
3: The cart casts off spokes. Husband and wife do not see eye to eye.
4: If there is trust, bloodshed will cease, but depart with vigilance.
No harm.
5: If there is solid trust, wealth will be found in your neighbor.
6: Rain, and a place of shelter. Virtue remains everywhere. An omen of danger for the woman.
The moon is nearly full. Inauspicious for the noble person to advance.

main: You are treading on the tiger's tail. The tiger does not bite. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
1: In going forth, tread with simplicity. No harm.
2: You are treading on a smooth and level path. For the person in seclusion, the omen is auspicious.
3: The half-blind can see, the lame can walk.
You are treading on the tiger's tail. The tiger bites. Inauspicious.
The warrior acts for the great prince.
4: You are treading on the tiger's tail. Frightful and terrifying. The end will be auspicious.
5: You are treading with great strides. An omen of danger.
6: Watch your steps and consider good fortune. A major auspicious omen will soon be seen.

main: Peace. Small things go, great things come. Auspicious. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
1: Pull up the reeds: gather them at the roots. Auspicious for the army to advance.
2: Embrace the wasteland and ford the river, but do not leave friends far behind.
Though friends have perished, there will still be gains in mid course.
3: There is no plain without uneven places, there is no going that does not return.
An omen of difficulties. No harm.
Do not be concerned with securing their trust: in the food offering is good fortune.
4: Grace and elegance. Poverty will occur through your neighbor.
Admonish no one and establish trust.
5: Emperor Yi gives his younger sister in marriage. Happiness.
A major auspicious omen.
6: The wall collapses into the moat. Do not send out the army.
Commands are issued from the city. An omen of misfortune.

main: Those who obstruct him are bandits.
The omen of the noble person is unfavorable. Great things go, small things come.
1: Pull up the reeds: gather them at the roots. The omen is auspicious.
Let a sacrifice be conducted.
2: Wrap up the offering and carry it. Auspicious for the lowly. The great person will be obstructed.
Let a sacrifice be conducted.
3: Wrap up the delicacies.
4: Destiny. No harm. Cultivate radiant happiness.
5: Obstructions cease. Auspicious for the great person.
Someone shall perish, someone shall perish, tied to the burgeoning mulberry tree!
6: Obstructions collapse: at first there are obstructions, then joy.

main: People gather in the field. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
It is favorable to ford the great river.
The omen of the noble person is favorable.
1: People gather at the gate. No harm.
2: People gather at the ancestral temple. Misfortune.
3: The army lies in ambush in the grass.
Scale the high hills. For three years you shall not prevail.
4: Enemies ride up to the wall, but cannot attack. Auspicious.
5: The people gather. First they cry and wail, but later there is laughter.
The great armies can meet.
6: People gather in the countryside. No regrets.

main: Great possession. Let a major sacrifice be conducted.
1: No mutual injury or harm. Difficulties, but no harm.
2: The great cart is loaded. Proceed with a purpose. No harm.
3: The duke conducts a sacrifice before the emperor. The lowly cannot do this.
4: Do not be overbearing. No harm.
5: Their trust is mutual and strong. Auspicious.
6: They receive heavenly protection. Auspicious. There is nothing that will not end favorably.

main: Modesty. Let a sacrifice be conducted. The noble person completes what he undertakes.
1: Modesty always. The noble person fords the great river. Auspicious.
2: Express modesty. The omen is auspicious.
3: Labor in modesty. The noble person completes what he undertakes.
Auspicious.
4: There is nothing that will not end favorably. Show modesty.
5: Poverty will occur through your neighbor.
It is favorable to invade and attack. There is nothing that will not end favorably.
6: Express modesty. It is favorable to send out the army, subduing cities and nations.

main: Happiness. The army.
1: You express happiness. Inauspicious.
2: There is armor on the rock, but it is gone by end of the day. The omen is auspicious.
3: Raise your eyes to happiness. Regrets: delay will bring regrets.
4: A cause for happiness. Great gains.
Do not doubt: friends will join like a clasp.
5: An omen of lasting illness, but you shall not die.
6: Happiness in a dark place. Achievement brings a change of heart. No harm.

main: Following. Let a major sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen. No harm.
1: Officials have a change of heart. The omen is auspicious.
To exit through the gate and meet will bring meritorious achievements.
2: You are tied to the small boy, but lose the powerful man.
3: You are tied to the powerful man, but lose the small boy.
Following brings the gains that are sought. A favorable omen for remaining at home.
4: Following brings acquisitions. The omen is inauspicious.
Maintaining trust on the road brings clarity. How could there be harm?
5: Trust in excellence. Auspicious.
6: Seize and tie him, then release him from his bonds.
The king conducts a sacrifice at the western mountain.

main: Corruption. Let a major sacrifice be conducted. It is favorable to ford the great river.
Wearing armor three days before, wearing armor three days after.
1: Deal with corruption caused by the father.
If there is a son, the deceased father shall suffer no blame.
Danger, but the end will be auspicious.
2: Deal with corruption caused by the mother. Do not engage in divination.
3: Deal with corruption caused by the father.
Regrets about small matters. No great harm.
4: Enrich what was corrupted by the father. When going forth, you will see misfortune.
5: Deal with corruption caused by the father. Express praise.
6: Do not serve kings and nobles. Place a high value on your own affairs.

main: Approaching. Let a major sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen.
The arrival of the eighth month brings ill fate.
1: A united approach. The omen is auspicious.
2: A united approach. Auspicious. There is nothing that will not end favorably.
3: You approach agreeably. There is no endeavor that will end favorably.
There has already been grieving about this. No harm.
4: You arrive and approach. No harm.
5: One must know how to approach. This befits a great prince.
Auspicious.
6: You approach with honesty. Auspicious. No harm.

main: Viewing. The ablutions have been made, but there is no worship. Maintaining trust is a noble thing.
1: Viewing like a child. No harm for the lowly. Misfortune for the noble person.
2: Viewing by peering in. The omen of the woman is favorable.
3: Viewing my life. Advancing and retreating.
4: Viewing the glory of the nation. It is favorable to be the guest of the king.
5: Viewing my life. The noble person will suffer no harm.
6: Viewing their lives. The noble person will suffer no harm.

main: Biting and snapping. Let a major sacrifice be conducted. It is favorable to invoke the law.
1: Sandals in the stocks, destruction of the feet. No harm.
2: Biting through flesh, destruction of the nose. No harm.
3: You bite into cured meat: you find poison.
A minor misfortune. No harm.
4: You bite into dry bones: you find a golden arrow.
The omen of difficulty is favorable. Auspicious.
5: You bite into dried meat: you find yellow gold.
An omen of danger. No harm.
6: Why must the stocks be used? Destruction of the ears. Inauspicious.

main: Adornment. Let a sacrifice be conducted. In small matters, it is favorable to proceed with a purpose.
1: The feet are adorned. Abandon the cart and walk.
2: The beard is adorned.
3: Adorned and anointed. The omen of eternity is auspicious.
4: Adorned and white: the white horse is soaring.
Robbers and bandits seeking marriage.
5: Adorned amidst hills and gardens. The bundle of silk is very thin.
Misfortune, but the end will be auspicious.
6: Adorned in white. No harm.

main: Splitting. It is not favorable to proceed with a purpose.
1: You split the bed and injure your foot. To disregard the omen is inauspicious.
2: You split the bed to show the demarcation. To disregard the omen is inauspicious.
3: You split the bed. No harm.
4: You split the bed and injure your skin. Inauspicious.
5: Take a string of fish to the occupant of the palace: you will find favor. There is nothing that will not end favorably.
6: Do not eat rich fruits.
The noble person gains a cart, but the huts of the lowly are destroyed.

main: Returning. Let a sacrifice be conducted. Going and coming, there will be no affliction. Friends arrive. No harm.
Reversing and returning on the road. You return after seven days.
It is favorable to proceed with a purpose.
1: You return from nearby. No great regrets. A major auspicious omen.
2: You return rested. Auspicious.
3: You return with urgency. There is danger, but no harm.
4: You return alone in mid course.
5: You return with sincerity. No regrets.
6: You return after being lost. Inauspicious. Calamity and error.
Engaging the army will end in a great defeat.
Inauspicious for the ruler of the nation.
For ten years the army must not advance.

main: The unexpected. Let a major sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen.
In acting without honesty, you will be in error. It is not favorable to proceed with a purpose.
1: You go forth unexpectedly. Auspicious.
2: If you can harvest without plowing, if you can plant without clearing the land, then it will be favorable to proceed with a purpose.
3: An unexpected calamity. Perhaps a tethered ox.
Gain for the traveler, calamity for the townspeople.
4: You can engage in divination. No harm.
5: An unexpected affliction. Without medicine all will end happily.
6: An unexpected voyage. An error. There is no endeavor that will end favorably.

main: A great offering of cattle. A favorable omen. Auspicious to dine away from home.
It is favorable to ford the great river.
1: Danger. It is favorable to desist.
2: The cart casts off spokes.
3: You give chase on a fine horse. The omen of difficulty is favorable.
Carts and guards stand idle for a day. It is favorable to proceed with a purpose.
4: The stall of a calf. A major auspicious omen.
5: The tusk of a gelded boar. Auspicious.
6: How can one gain the way of heaven? Let a sacrifice be conducted.

main: Cheeks. The omen is auspicious. View the cheeks. Seek sustenance for yourself.
1: Abandon your tortoise shell divination. View my swollen cheeks. Inauspicious.
2: Sunken cheeks. Reject the path at the rounded hill. Inauspicious for the army to advance.
3: Reject the cheeks. The omen is inauspicious.
Do not act for ten years. There is no endeavor that will end favorably.
4: Sunken cheeks. Auspicious.
The tiger watches, staring, staring. It longs to run in swift pursuit. No harm.
5: Reject the path. An auspicious omen for remaining at home.
Do not ford the great river.
6: Because of the cheeks: even in danger, the omen is auspicious.
It is favorable to ford the great river.

main: Great excess. The ridgepole is twisted. It is favorable to proceed with a purpose. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
1: Use white reeds to wrap the offering. No harm.
2: The withered willow brings forth shoots.
The old man gains a wife.
There is nothing that will not end favorably.
3: The ridgepole is twisted. Inauspicious.
4: The ridgepole is sturdy. Auspicious. If you undertake extraneous affairs, there will be misfortune.
5: The withered willow brings forth blossoms.
The old woman gains a husband.
Neither harm nor praise.
6: While fording the river, your head is submerged. Inauspicious.
No harm.

main: Continuous watery pits. There is trust safeguarding the heart. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
Going forth is beneficial.
1: Continuous watery pits. You enter into the watery pit. Inauspicious.
2: The watery pit holds danger. Seek small gains.
3: Coming and going: watery pits, watery pits. Danger even in resting.
You enter into the watery pit. Do not act.
4: A glass of wine and a platter, both of earthenware.
Receive these simple objects through the window. In the end there will be no harm.
5: The watery pit is not full, but the surface is already smooth. No harm.
6: Tied and bound with ropes, placed in a thicket of thorns.
For three years there will be no gains. Inauspicious.

main: Fire. A favorable omen. Let a sacrifice be conducted. Auspicious to raise a cow.
1: You tread onward, alternating the feet. Show respect. No harm.
2: Yellow fire. A major auspicious omen.
3: The fire of the setting sun.
When one no longer drums on earthen jars and sings, then there is only the lament of old age.
Inauspicious.
4: Dashing forth, coming forth. Burning, dying, and being abandoned.
5: Tears flow in torrents, a mournful lament. Auspicious.
6: The king sets out and advances. There is a good executioner, but it is not the enemy that is captured. No harm.

main: Unity. Let a sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen. Auspicious to choose a wife.
1: Unity is expressed in the thumbs.
2: Unity is expressed in the calves. Inauspicious.
Auspicious to remain at home.
3: Unity is expressed in the thighs: they persist in their following. Going forth will bring misfortune.
4: The omen is auspicious. Regrets will disappear.
Uncertain and worried, you pace back and forth. Friends begin to think of you.
5: Unity is expressed in the neck. No regrets.
6: Unity is expressed in the jaw, cheeks, and tongue.

main: Constancy. Let a sacrifice be conducted. No harm. A favorable omen.
It is favorable to proceed with a purpose.
1: Lasting submersion. The omen is inauspicious. There is no endeavor that will end favorably.
2: Regrets will disappear.
3: Your virtue is inconstant. Perhaps you will bear the shame.
An omen of misfortune.
4: No fowl are in the field.
5: Your virtue is constant. The omen is auspicious for a woman, inauspicious for a man.
6: Agitating with constancy. Inauspicious.

main: Retreat. Let a sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen for small matters.
1: A tail in retreat. Danger. Do not attempt to proceed with a purpose.
2: Hold the beast with a rope of yellow ox hide.
The beast will not manage to break free of it.
3: An impeded retreat. A danger of illness.
Auspicious to retain servants and concubines.
4: A successful retreat. Auspicious for the noble person. The lowly person will be obstructed.
5: An excellent retreat. The omen is auspicious.
6: A fertile retreat. There is nothing that will not end favorably.

main: Great strength. A favorable omen.
1: Strength in the feet. Inauspicious for the army to advance. There is trust.
2: The omen is auspicious.
3: The lowly person uses force. The noble person outwits his opponents.
An omen of danger. The ram butts the fence, but its horns are weak.
4: The omen is auspicious. Regrets will disappear.
The fence breaks through, its horns are not weak. Strength is in the axle strap of the great cart.
5: You lose a goat in a time of ease. No regrets.
6: The ram butts the fence. It cannot retreat, it cannot advance.
There is no endeavor that will end favorably. Difficulties lie ahead, but the omen is auspicious.

main: Advancing. Marquis Kang presents the king with horses in abundance.
Each day he is granted three audiences.
1: Advance and destroy. The omen is auspicious.
Though trust has been betrayed, there is abundance. No harm.
2: You advance, but you are worried. The omen is auspicious.
Now you receive armor and blessings from the mother of the king.
3: The multitude consent. Regrets will disappear.
4: You are advancing like a flying squirrel. An omen of danger.
5: Regrets will disappear. Do not be concerned with losses and gains.
It is auspicious to go forth. There is nothing that will not end favorably.
6: The ram advances with its horns. Hold firm in striking the city.
Even in danger, the omen is auspicious. No harm, but an omen of misfortune.

main: The bright pheasant. The omen of difficulty is favorable.
1: The bright pheasant flies, drooping its wings.
The noble person travels, fasting for three days.
Proceed with a purpose. The master will speak.
2: The bright pheasant. You suffer an injury in the left thigh, but are rescued. The horse is strong. Auspicious.
3: The bright pheasant flies. You go hunting in the south and claim the great head of the beast.
The omen reveals that you must not hasten.
4: The arrow enters on the left side of the body.
You pierce the heart of the bright pheasant as you depart through the gated courtyard.
5: The bright pheasant of prince ji. A favorable omen.
6: No light. Darkness.
First the bright pheasant ascends to the sky, then it plummets toward the earth.

main: The family. The omen of the woman is favorable.
1: The household is protected. Regrets will disappear.
2: No purpose is fulfilled, but in the center food is presented. The omen is auspicious.
3: Dissension in the family. Then all regret the discord. Auspicious.
Women and children laughing, laughing. In the end there will be misfortune.
4: A wealthy household. A great auspicious omen.
5: When the king arrives, the household has been established. Do not be concerned. Auspicious.
6: Their trust is strong. The end will be auspicious.

main: Disunity. Auspicious for small affairs.
1: Regrets will disappear. Do not pursue a lost horse. It will return on its own.
You see an enemy. No harm.
2: You meet the master in the lane. No harm.
3: You see a cart pulled along, drawn by an ox.
A person's head, the nose is severed.
Affairs which did not at first succeed end well.
4: Disunited and alone. You meet a man with whom there is fundamental accord. Mutual trust.
There is danger, but no harm.
5: Regrets will disappear. Their clan feast on meat. How could there be harm in going forth?
6: Disunited and alone. You see a pig covered with mud and a cart bearing demons.
First a bow that is drawn, then a bow that is withdrawn.
Robbers and bandits seeking marriage.
In going forth you meet with rain, but the omen is auspicious.

main: Impediments. Favorable in the southwest, unfavorable in the northeast.
It is favorable to see the great person. The omen is auspicious.
1: In going there are impediments, in coming there is praise.
2: Impediments abound for the king and his ministers, but not of their own creation.
3: In going there are impediments, in coming there is opposition.
4: In going there are impediments, in coming there are connections.
5: Amidst great impediments a friend arrives.
6: In going there are impediments, in coming there is greatness. Auspicious.
It is favorable to see the great person.

main: Release.
Favorable in the southwest.
Nowhere to go. Auspicious to return.
In proceeding with a purpose, it is auspicious to be early.
1: No harm.
2: You bag three foxes in the field. You gain a yellow arrow. The omen is auspicious.
3: Bearing the load on the back or using a cart causes bandits to come.
An omen of misfortune.
4: Release your thumb. When friends arrive there will be trust.
5: The noble person controls the release. Auspicious.
There is trust among the lowly.
6: The duke aims at a falcon atop the high wall. He strikes it.
There is nothing that will not end favorably.

main: Decrease. There is trust. A major auspicious omen.
No harm. You can engage in divination. It is favorable to proceed with a purpose.
How should one proceed? Using two platters, you can conduct the sacrifice.
1: When your affairs are completed, go quickly. No harm. In pouring the wine, reduce the amount.
2: A favorable omen. Inauspicious for the army to advance. Do not decrease the amount. Increase it.
3: Three people go, but are decreased by one.
One person goes, but finds his friend.
4: Your affliction subsides, soon bringing forth joy. No harm.
5: Perhaps increase the amount. Use ten pairs of tortoise shells. Such an omen cannot be opposed.
A major auspicious omen.
6: Do not decrease the amount. Increase it. No harm. The omen is auspicious.
It is favorable to proceed with a purpose. You gain a homeless servant.

main: Increase. It is favorable to proceed with a purpose. It is favorable to ford the great river.
1: It is favorable to undertake great acts. A major auspicious omen. No harm.
2: Perhaps increase the amount. Use ten pairs of tortoise shells. Such an omen cannot be opposed.
The omen of eternity is auspicious. The king conducts a sacrifice before the gods. Auspicious.
3: To increase the amount would produce an inauspicious outcome. No harm. There is trust.
The duke is informed in mid course. The messenger uses a jade tablet.
4: The duke is informed in mid course. Plans are enacted.
It is favorable to make all comply in moving the capital of the nation.
5: When there is trust and the heart is kind, you need not ask.
A major auspicious omen.
When there is trust, kindness is my virtue.
6: Do not increase the amount. Perhaps undertake an attack.
You have directed your heart without constancy. Inauspicious.

main: Striding forward. An announcement is made at the court of the king. A cry of solidarity.
Danger. Reports come in from the cities. It is not favorable for the army to advance.
It is favorable to proceed with a purpose.
1: Strength in the forward-striding feet. Going forth will bring no victory, but only harm.
2: Cries of alarm: soldiers advancing night after night. Do not be concerned.
3: Strength in the cheekbones. Inauspicious. The noble person keeps striding forward.
Walking alone, you meet with rain. Soon you are wet. Anger, no harm.
4: The buttocks are withered. You walk with great difficulty.
You lead a goat. Regrets will disappear. Do not believe the words you hear.
5: You stride forward through fields of amaranths. In mid course there will be no harm.
6: No cries, but the end will bring ill fate.

main: A match. The woman is strong. Do not choose the woman.
1: Tied to a golden block. The omen is auspicious.
Proceeding with a purpose, you will see ill fate. One can trust even a weak pig to pace about.
2: In the wrapping there is a fish. No harm. It is inauspicious to be a guest.
3: The buttocks are withered. You walk with great difficulty.
Danger, but no great harm.
4: In the wrapping there is no fish. This is the beginning of ill fate.
5: Use willow leaves to wrap the melons.
Maintain your integrity. Disaster will descend from heaven.
6: The rams lock horns. An omen of misfortune, but no harm.

main: Gathering. Temple has let a sacrifice be conducted. When the king arrives the been established.
It is favorable to see the great person.
Let a sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen. Auspicious to make a great offering of cattle.
It is favorable to proceed with a purpose.
1: When there is incomplete trust, there will be tumult and gatherings of people.
If there is wailing, one embrace will produce laughter. Do not be concerned. Going forth will bring no harm.
2: It is auspicious to if there is trust, then it is favorable to conduct the spring offering.
Invite guests. No harm.
3: Gathering and lamenting. There is no endeavor that will end favorably.
Going forth will bring no harm, but only a minor misfortune.
4: A great auspicious omen. No harm.
5: At the gathering you gain a position of respect. No harm, but no trust. A major auspicious omen.
The omen of eternity. Regrets will disappear.
6: Sighing, sighing, weeping and wailing. No harm.

main: Ascending. Let a major sacrifice be conducted. See the great person. Do not be concerned.
Auspicious for the army to advance to the south.
1: You are permitted to ascend. A great auspicious omen.
2: If there is trust, then it is favorable to conduct the spring offering. No harm.
3: You ascend to an empty city.
4: The king conducts a sacrifice at mount Qi. Auspicious. No harm.
5: The omen is auspicious. Ascend the steps.
6: You ascend in the dark. An omen of advantage through persevering without rest.

main: Oppression. Let a sacrifice be conducted. The omen is auspicious for the great person. No harm.
Do not believe the words that are spoken.
1: You sit, oppressed, against a tree trunk.
You enter into the distant valley. For three years you are not seen.
2: You are oppressed while partaking of wine and food. The official with the vermilion sash enters from the side.
It is favorable to conduct sacrifices. Inauspicious for the army to advance. No harm.
3: Oppressed among the stones, seized among the star thistles.
Entering into his palace, one does not see his wife. Inauspicious.
4: You approach slowly, slowly, oppressed in a golden cart. Yet misfortune is nearing an end.
5: Severing of the nose, amputation of the feet. You are oppressed by the official with the red sash.
Then, slowly, oppression recedes. It is favorable to conduct sacrifices.
6: You are oppressed among the kudzu vines, amidst uncertainty and doubt.
As you move on, day by day, there are regrets and more regrets. Auspicious for the army to advance.

main: The well. Change the city, but do not change the well. No losses, no gains.
Comings and goings at the well. The well is nearly dry.
Nor is a rope to be found at the well. Your jug is fragile. Inauspicious.
1: The well is muddy, do not drink. An old well, no fowl.
2: The well in the valley. Shooting at carp. The urn is broken and leaking.
3: The well flows forth, but do not drink. This brings sadness to my heart.
You can draw water. When the king is enlightened, all receive the blessings of the well.
4: The well is lined with bricks. No harm.
5: The water is cold: an ice-cold spring. Drink!
6: Let the well be used, do not cover it. There is trust. A major auspicious omen.

main: Revolt. On the sixth day there will be trust. Let a major sacrifice be conducted.
A favorable omen. Regrets will disappear.
1: The beast is tied with a rope of yellow ox hide.
2: On the sixth day, let the revolt begin. Auspicious for the army to advance. No harm.
3: Inauspicious for the army to advance. An omen of danger. Incitements to revolt are thrice pronounced.
There is trust.
4: Regrets will disappear. When there is trust, the ruler can be replaced. Auspicious.
5: The great person is as changeable as a tiger. Before the divination there is trust.
6: The noble person is as changeable as a leopard. The lowly change only on the surface.
Inauspicious for the army to advance. An auspicious omen for remaining at home.

main: The tripod. A major auspicious omen. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
1: The feet of the tripod are overturned. Favorable for expelling the obstruction.
Taking a concubine to bear a son. No harm.
2: My tripod is full of food. My enemies suffer affliction.
I am not within their reach. Auspicious.
3: The tripod's ears have been removed.
It has been stuffed to the top, but the pheasant grease is not eaten.
When it rains, regrets will vanish. The end will be auspicious.
4: The feet snap off the tripod: the duke's repast is overturned, the tripod's form is sullied.
Inauspicious.
5: A tripod with yellow ears, golden handles. A favorable omen.
6: A tripod with jade handles. A great auspicious omen. There is nothing that will not end favorably.

main: Thunder. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
The thunder comes, instilling dread, yet one laughs and talks.
The thunderclap is heard a hundred miles, yet not one ladle of sacrificial wine is spilled.
1: After the thunder comes, instilling dread, there is laughter and merriment. Auspicious.
2: The thunder comes, bringing danger. A hundred thousand cowrie shells are lost.
Even if he climbs to the nine hills, do not pursue him. In seven days he will be taken.
3: The thunder revives, but while it rumbles there will be no error.
4: Thunder and then mud.
5: The thunder comes and goes. Danger. You have not forgotten your intentions: there are tasks ahead.
6: The thunder threatens. You watch in terror. Inauspicious for the army to advance.
The thunder does not strike you, but strikes your neighbor. No harm.
There is talk of marriage.

main: Your back is motionless. You will not be captured.
Walking in your courtyard. You are not seen. No harm.
1: Your feet are motionless. No harm. The omen of eternity is favorable.
2: Your calves are motionless. You cannot save your followers.
Your heart is not glad.
3: The threshold of your body is motionless. Your sacrum is aligned.
Danger. Your heart is stifled.
4: Your body is motionless. No harm.
5: Your jaws are firm. Your speech is orderly. Regrets will disappear.
6: You are sincere and motionless. Auspicious.

main: A gradual approach. Auspicious for the woman to marry. A favorable omen.
1: The wild goose gradually nears the dry land. Danger for the youngest son.
A discussion. No harm.
2: The wild goose gradually nears the cliff. Joyful eating and drinking. Auspicious.
3: The wild goose gradually nears the land.
The husband sets forth but does not return. The wife conceives but bears no child.
Inauspicious. It is favorable to ward off enemies.
4: The wild goose gradually nears the trees. Perhaps it will find a perch. No harm.
5: The wild goose gradually nears the hill. For three years the wife will not conceive.
In the end, nothing prevents it. Auspicious.
6: The wild goose gradually nears the land.
Its feathers can be used to conduct the rites. Auspicious.

main: The marrying maiden the marrying maiden. Inauspicious for the army to advance. There is no endeavor that will end favorably.
1: The marrying maiden takes along a secondary wife.
The lame can walk. Auspicious for the army to advance.
2: The half-blind can see. The omen of the person in seclusion is favorable.
3: The marrying maiden takes along a handmaiden.
When the marriage is at an end, she takes along the secondary wife.
4: The marrying maiden exceeds the appointed date. There is time to postpone the marriage.
5: Emperor Yi gives his younger sister in marriage.
The sleeves of the monarch are not as splendid as the sleeves of the secondary wife.
The moon is nearly full. Auspicious.
6: The woman bears a basket, but there is nothing in it.
The young man stabs a sheep, but there is no blood.
There is no endeavor that will end favorably.

main: Abundance. Let a sacrifice be conducted. The king arrives. Do not be troubled. It is fitting to act at midday.
1: You meet with your counterpart and master. Even after ten days, there will be no harm.
Going forth is beneficial.
2: Your curtain is abundant. The big dipper is seen at midday.
Going forth brings doubts and afflictions, but trust is developing.
Auspicious.
3: Your banner is abundant. Swirling waters are seen at midday.
You break your right arm. No harm.
4: Your curtain is abundant. The big dipper is seen at midday.
You meet with your master in safety. Auspicious.
5: You come with integrity. There are rewards and praise. Auspicious.
6: Your house is abundant, yet your household is curtained off.
One peers through your door, yet sees no one.
You are not seen for three years. Inauspicious.

main: The traveler the traveler. Let a minor sacrifice be conducted. The omen of the traveler is auspicious.
1: Absorbed with trivialities, the traveler leaves his dwelling, courting disaster.
2: The traveler reaches an inn, embracing his money. He acquires a child servant.
The omen is auspicious.
3: The traveler's inn is burning. He loses the child servant. An omen of danger.
4: The traveler is in a safe place. He gets his money and his ax. My heart is not glad.
5: You shoot a pheasant. One arrow is lost. In the end, you will gain praise and rank.
6: The bird's nest is burning. The traveler first laughs, then cries and wails.
You lose an ox in a time of ease. Inauspicious.

main: Cowardice. Let a minor sacrifice be conducted. It is favorable to proceed with a purpose.
It is favorable to see the great person.
1: Advancing and retreating. The omen of the warrior is favorable.
2: Cowardly, you hide beneath the bed. You utilize spell-casters and sorcerers in profusion.
Auspicious. No harm.
3: You are frantic and cowardly. Misfortune.
4: Regrets will disappear. In the field you bag three types of game.
5: The omen is auspicious. Regrets will disappear. There is nothing that will not end favorably.
Affairs which did not at first succeed have a good culmination.
Three days before the seventh. Three days after the seventh. Auspicious.
6: Cowardly, you hide beneath the bed. You lose your money and your ax.
The omen is inauspicious.

main: Joy. Let a sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen.
1: Peace with joy. Auspicious.
2: Trust amidst joy. Auspicious. Regrets will disappear.
3: Joy comes, yet the omens are inauspicious.
4: Discussions are joyful, yet there is no peace. You are protected against affliction. Joy will prevail.
5: There is trust amidst dissent. Danger.
6: Joy is brought forth.

main: Flowing. Let a sacrifice be conducted. When the king arrives the temple has been established.
It is favorable to ford the great river. A favorable omen.
1: You are rescued. The horse is strong. Auspicious.
2: Flowing water, splashing over your table. Regrets will disappear.
3: Water flowing over you. No regrets.
4: Water flowing over your flock. A major auspicious omen.
The flowing water reaches the hill. Your thoughts are of danger.
5: The sweat is flowing. Great cries sound forth. Water flowing over the residence of the king. No harm.
6: Blood is flowing. Go, escape to a distant place! No harm.

main: Restraint. Let a sacrifice be conducted. Bitter restraint. Do not engage in divination.
1: Do not depart through the courtyard by the door. No harm.
2: Do not depart through the courtyard by the gate. Inauspicious.
3: Those who do not practice restraint will lament. No harm.
4: Peaceful restraint. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
5: Pleasant restraint. Auspicious. Going forth is beneficial.
6: Bitter restraint. The omen is inauspicious, but regrets will disappear.

main: Inmost trust. Swine and fish are auspicious.
It is favorable to ford the great river. A favorable omen.
1: Vigilance is auspicious. If you undertake extraneous affairs, you will lose the serenity of swallows.
2: The crane calls in the shade. It is joined by its young.
I have a good vessel of wine. I will share it with you.
3: Defeating the enemy. Perhaps there is drumming, perhaps the drumming ceases. Perhaps there is weeping, perhaps there is singing.
4: The moon is nearly full. A team of horses goes astray. No harm.
5: There is solid trust. No harm.
6: The sound of wings ascends to the sky. The omen is inauspicious.

main: Small excess. Let a sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen.
You can engage in small affairs. Do not engage in great affairs.
The sound left behind by a flying bird. It is not fitting to go high. It is fitting to stay low.
A great auspicious omen.
1: A flying bird will bring ill fate.
2: You pass by your grandfather, but meet with your grandmother.
You do not reach the monarch, but meet with his minister. No harm.
3: Do not pass him by: defend yourself against him. Perhaps undertake to kill him. Inauspicious.
4: No harm. Do not pass him by: meet with him. Going forth will bring danger. You must be on your guard.
Do not act. An omen of eternity.
5: Thick clouds without rain, approaching from my western fields.
The duke shoots with the string-arrow, striking the one in the cave.
6: Do not meet with him: pass him by. Flying birds leave him behind.
Inauspicious: this will be called a calamitous error.

main: After crossing the river. Let a sacrifice be conducted. A favorable omen for small affairs.
Auspicious at first, but the end brings disarray.
1: You are dragging your wheels. The fox gets its tail wet. No harm.
2: The woman loses her headdress. Do not seek after it. In seven days it will be found.
3: The exalted ancestor attacked the place of demons. In three years he conquered it.
The lowly person must not act.
4: Fine clothes end up in tatters. Until the end of the day, be on your guard.
5: When the eastern neighbor slaughters an ox the rites are not as splendid as the spring sacrifices of the western neighbor.
There is good fortune in solidity.
6: You get your head wet. Danger.

main: Before crossing the river. Let a sacrifice be conducted.
When the small fox has nearly crossed the river, it gets its tail wet. There is no endeavor that will end favorably.
1: The fox gets its tail wet. Misfortune.
2: You are dragging your wheels. The omen is auspicious.
3: Before crossing the river it is inauspicious for the army to advance.
It is favorable to ford the great river.
4: The omen is auspicious. Regrets will disappear. Like a thunderclap, attack the place of demons.
In three years, rewards will be obtained in the great realm.
5: The omen is auspicious. No regrets.
There is trust in the honor of the noble person. Auspicious.
6: Trust is gained in the drinking of wine. No harm.
You get your head wet. Though there is trust, you may stray from what is right.

main: Qián (represents) what is great and originating, penetrating, advantageous, correct and firm.

Vast is the 'great and originating (power)' indicated by Qián! All things owe to it their beginning: – it contains all the meaning belonging to (the name) heaven. The clouds move and the rain is distributed; the various things appear in their developed forms. (The sages) grandly understand (the connexion between) the end and the beginning, and how (the indications of) the six lines (in the hexagram) are accomplished, (each) in its season. (Accordingly) they mount (the carriage) drawn by those six dragons at the proper times, and drive through the sky. The method of Qián is to change and transform, so that everything obtains its correct nature as appointed (by the mind of Heaven); and (thereafter the conditions of) great harmony are preserved in union. The result is 'what is advantageous, and correct and firm. (The sage) appears aloft, high above all things, and the myriad states all enjoy repose.
Heaven, in its motion, (gives the idea of) strength. The superior man, in accordance with this, nerves himself to ceaseless activity.
1: In the first (or lowest) NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the dragon lying hid (in the deep). It is not the time for active doing.
'The dragon lies hid in the deep; – it is not the time for active doing:' – (this appears from) the strong and undivided line's being in the lowest place.
2: In the second NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the dragon appearing in the field. It will be advantageous to meet with the great man.
'The dragon appears in the field:' – the diffusion of virtuous influence has been wide.
3: In the third NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the superior man active and vigilant all the day, and in the evening still careful and apprehensive. (The position is) dangerous, but there will be no mistake.
'Active and vigilant all the day:' – (this refers to) the treading of the (proper) path over and over again.
4: In the fourth NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as the dragon looking) as if he were leaping up, but still in the deep. There will be no mistake.
'He seems to be leaping up, but is still in the deep:' – if he advance, there will be no error.
5: In the fifth NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the dragon on the wing in the sky. It will be advantageous to meet with the great man.
'The dragon is on the wing in the sky:' – the great man rouses himself to his work.
6: In the sixth (or topmost) NINE, undivided, (we see its subject as) the dragon exceeding the proper limits. There will be occasion for repentance.
'The dragon exceeds the proper limits; – there will be occasion for repentance:' – a state of fulness, that is, should not be indulged in long.
7: (The lines of this hexagram are all strong and undivided, as appears from) the use of the number NINE. If the host of dragons (thus) appearing were to divest themselves of their heads, there would be good fortune.

main: Kūn (represents) what is great and originating, penetrating, advantageous, correct and having the firmness of a mare. When the superior man (here intended) has to make any movement, if he take the initiative, he will go astray; if he follow, he will find his (proper) lord. The advantageousness will be seen in his getting friends in the south-west, and losing friends in the north-east. If he rest in correctness and firmness, there will be good fortune.

Complete is the 'great and originating (capacity)' indicated by Kūn! All things owe to it their birth; – it receives obediently the influences of Heaven. Kūn, in its largeness, supports and contains all things. Its excellent capacity matches the unlimited power (of Qián). Its comprehension is wide, and its brightness great. The various things obtain (by it) their full development. The mare is a creature of earthly kind. Its (power of) moving on the earth is without limit; it is mild and docile, advantageous and firm: – such is the course of the superior man. 'If he take the initiative, he goes astray:' – he misses, that is, his proper course. 'If he follow,' he is docile, and gets into his regular (course). 'In the south-west he will get friends:' – he will be walking with those of his own class. 'In the north-east he will lose friends:' – but in the end there will be ground for congratulation. 'The good fortune arising from resting in firmness' corresponds to the unlimited capacity of the earth.
The (capacity and sustaining) power of the earth is what is denoted by Kūn. The superior man, in accordance with this, with his large virtue supports (men and) things.
1: In the first SIX, divided, (we see its subject) treading on hoarfrost. The strong ice will come (by and by).

'He is treading on hoarfrost; – the strong ice will come (by and by):' – the cold (air) has begun to take form. Allow it to go on quietly according to its nature, and (the hoarfrost) will come to strong ice.
2: The second SIX, divided, (shows the attribute of) being straight, square, and great. (Its operation), without repeated efforts, will be in every respect advantageous.

The movement indicated by the second six, (divided),is 'from the straight (line) to the square.' '(Its operation), without repeated effort, in every way advantageous,' shows the brilliant result of the way of earth.
3: The third SIX, divided, (shows its subject) keeping his excellence under restraint, but firmly maintaining it. If he should have occasion to engage in the king's service, though he will not claim the success (for himself), he will bring affairs to a good issue.

'He keeps his excellence tinder restraint, but firmly maintains it:' – at the proper time he will manifest it. 'He may have occasion to engage in the king's service: – great is the glory of his wisdom.
4: The fourth SIX, divided, (shows the symbol of) a sack tied up. There will be no ground for blame or for praise.
'A sack tied up; – there will be no error:' – this shows how, through carefulness, no injury will be received.
5: The fifth SIX, divided, (shows) the yellow lower garment. There will be great good fortune.
'The Yellow lower-garment; – there will be great good fortune:' – this follows from that ornamental (colour's) being in the right and central place.
6: The sixth SIX, divided (shows) dragons fighting in the wild. Their blood is purple and yellow.
'The dragons fight in the wild: – the (onward) course (indicated by Kūn) is pursued to extremity.
7: '(The lines are all weak and divided, as appears from) the use of the number SIX: - but (those who are thus represented) becoming perpetually correct and firm, there will thereby be a great consummation.

main: Zhūn (indicates that in the case which it presupposes) there will be great progress and success, and the advantage will come from being correct and firm. (But) any movement in advance should not be (lightly) undertaken. There will be advantage in appointing feudal princes.

In Zhūn we have the strong (Qián) and the weak (Kūn) commencing their intercourse, and difficulties arising. Movement in the midst of peril gives rise to 'great progress and success, (through) firm correctness.' By the action of the thunder and rain, (which are symbols of Kǎn and Zhèn), all (between heaven and earth) is filled up. But the condition of the time is full of irregularity and obscurity. Feudal princes should be established, but the feeling that rest and peace have been secured should not be indulged (even then).

(The trigram representing) clouds and (that representing) thunder form Zhūn. The superior man, in accordance with this, (adjusts his measures of government) as in sorting the threads of the warp and woof.
1: The first NINE, undivided, shows the difficulty (its subject has) in advancing. It will be advantageous for him to abide correct and firm; advantageous (also) to be made a feudal ruler.
Although 'there is a difficulty in advancing,' the mind (of the subject of the line) is set on doing what is correct. While noble, he humbles himself to the mean, and grandly gains the people.
2: The second SIX, divided, shows (its subject) distressed and obliged to return; (even) the horses of her chariot (also) seem to be retreating. (But) not by a spoiler (is she assailed), but by one who seeks her to be his wife. The young lady maintains her firm correctness, and declines a union. After ten years she will be united, and have children.

The difficulty (to the subject of) the second six, (divided), arises from, its place over the undivided line below it. 'The union and children after ten years' shows things resuming their regular course.
3: The third SIX, divided, shows one following the deer without (the guidance of) the forester, and only finding himself in the midst of the forest. The superior man, acquainted with the secret risks, thinks it better to give up the chase. If he went forward, he would regret it.

'One pursues the deer without the (guidance of the) forester:' – (he does so) in (his eagerness to) follow the game. 'The superior man gives up the chase, (knowing that) if he go forward he will regret it:' – he would be reduced to extremity.
4: The fourth SIX, divided, shows (its subject as a lady), the horses of whose chariot appear in retreat. She seeks, however, (the help of) him who seeks her to be his wife. Advance will be fortunate; all will turn out advantageously.
'Going forward after such a search (for a helper)' shows intelligence.
5: The fifth NINE, undivided, shows the difficulties in the way of (its subject's) dispensing the rich favours that might be expected from him. With firmness and correctness there will be good fortune in small things; (even) with them in great things there will be evil.
'Difficulty is experienced (by the subject of the fifth line) in bestowing his rich favours:' – the extent to which they reach will not yet be conspicuous.
6: The topmost SIX, divided, shows (its subject) with the horses of his chariot obliged to retreat, and weeping tears of blood in streams.
'He weeps tears of blood in streams:' – how can the state (thus emblemed) continue long?

main: Méng (indicates that in the case which it presupposes) there will be progress and success. I do not (go and) seek the youthful and inexperienced, but he comes and seeks me. When he shows (the sincerity that marks) the first recourse to divination, I instruct him. If he apply a second and third time, that is troublesome; and I do not instruct the troublesome. There will be advantage in being firm and correct.

In Méng we have (the trigram for) a mountain, and below it that of a rugged defile with a stream in it. The conditions of peril and arrest of progress (suggested by these) give (the idea in) Méng. 'Méng indicates that there will be progress and success:' – for there is development at work in it, and its time of action is exactly what is right. 'I do not seek the youthful and inexperienced; he seeks me:' – so does will respond to will. 'When he shows (the sincerity that marks) the first recourse to divination, I instruct him:' – for possessing the qualities of the undivided line and being in the central place, (the subject of the second line thus speaks). 'A second and third application create annoyance, and I do not instruct so as to create annoyance:' – annoyance (he means) to the ignorant. (The method of dealing with) the young and ignorant is to nourish the correct (nature belonging to them); – this accomplishes the service of the sage.

(The trigram representing) a mountain, and beneath it that for a spring issuing forth form Méng. The superior man, in accordance with this, strives to be resolute in his conduct and nourishes his virtue.
1: The first SIX, divided, (has respect to) the dispelling of ignorance. It will be advantageous to use punishment (for that purpose), and to remove the shackles (from the mind). But going on in that way (of punishment) will give occasion for regret.
'It will be advantageous to use punishment:' – the object being to bring under the influence of correcting law.
2: The second NINE, undivided, (shows its subject) exercising forbearance with the ignorant, in which there will be good fortune; and admitting (even the goodness of women, which will also be fortunate. (He may be described also as) a son able to (sustain the burden of) his family.
'A son able to (sustain the burden of) his family:' – as appears from the reciprocation between this strong line and the weak (fifth line).
3: The third SIX, divided, (seems to say) that one should not marry a woman whose emblem it might be, for that, when she sees a man of wealth, she will not keep her person from him, and in no wise will advantage come from her.
'A woman (such as is here represented) should not be taken in marriage:' – her conduct is not agreeable to what is right.
4: The fourth SIX, divided, (shows its subject as if) bound in chains of ignorance. There will be occasion for regret.
'The regret arising from ignorance bound in chains' is due to the special distance of (the subject of this line) from the solidity (shown in lines 2 and 6).
5: The fifth SIX, divided, shows its subject as a simple lad without experience. There will be good fortune.
'The good fortune belonging to the simple lad without experience' comes from his docility going on to humility.
6: In the topmost NINE, undivided, we see one smiting the ignorant (youth). But no advantage will come from doing him an injury. Advantage would come from warding off injury from him.
'Advantage will come from warding off injury:' – (the subject of this line) above and (the ignorant) below, all do and are done to in accordance with their nature.

main: Xū intimates that, with the sincerity which is declared in it, there will be brilliant success. With firmness there will be good fortune; and it will be advantageous to cross the great stream.

Xū denotes waiting. (The figure) shows peril in front; but notwithstanding the firmness and strength (indicated by the inner trigram), its subject does not allow himself to be involved (in the dangerous defile); – it is right he should not be straitened or reduced to extremity. When it is said that, 'with the sincerity declared in Xū, there will be brilliant success, and with firmness there will be good fortune,' this is shown by the position (of the fifth line) in the place assigned by Heaven, and its being the correct position for it, and in the centre. 'It will be advantageous to go through the great stream;' – that is, going forward will be followed by meritorious achievement.
(The trigram for) clouds ascending over that for the sky forms Xū. The superior man, in accordance with this, eats and drinks, feasts and enjoys himself (as if there were nothing else to employ him).
1: The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject waiting in the distant border. It will be well for him constantly to maintain (the purpose thus shown), in which case there will be no error.

'He is waiting in the (distant) border:' – he makes no movement to encounter rashly the difficulties (of the situation). 'It will be advantageous for him constantly to maintain (the purpose thus shown), in which case there will be no error:' – he will not fail to pursue that regular course.
2: The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject waiting on the sand (of the mountain stream). He will (suffer) the small (injury of) being spoken (against), but in the end there will be good fortune.
'He is waiting on the sand:' – he occupies his position in the centre with a generous forbearance. Though 'he suffer the small injury of being spoken (against),' he will bring things to a good issue.
3: The third NINE, undivided, shows its subject in the mud (close by the stream). He thereby invites the approach of injury.
'He is waiting in the mud:' – calamity is (close at hand, and as it were) in the outer (trigram). 'He himself invites the approach of injury:' – if he be reverent and careful, he will not be worsted.
4: The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject waiting in (the place of) blood. But he will get out of the cavern.
'He is waiting in (the place of) blood:' – he accommodates himself (to the circumstances of the time), and hearkens to (its requirements).
5: The fifth NINE, undivided, shows its subject waiting amidst the appliances of a feast. Through his firmness and correctness there will be good fortune.
'The appliances of a feast, and the good fortune through being firm and correct,' are indicated by (the position in) the central and correct place.
6: The topmost SIX, divided, shows its subject entered into the cavern. (But) there are three guests coming, without being urged, (to his help). If he receive them respectfully, there will be good fortune in the end.

'Guests come unurged (to give their help), and if (the subject of the line) receive them respectfully, there will be good fortune in the end:' – though the occupant and the place are not suited to each other, there has been no great failure (in what has been done).

main: Sòng intimates how, though there is sincerity in one's contention, he will yet meet with opposition and obstruction; but if he cherish an apprehensive caution, there will be good fortune, while, if he must prosecute the contention to the (bitter) end, there will be evil. It will be advantageous to see the great man; it will not be advantageous to cross the great stream.

The upper portion of Sòng is (the trigram representing) strength, and the lower (that representing) peril. (The coming together of) strength and peril gives (the idea in) Sòng. 'Sòng intimates how, though there is sincerity in one's contention, he will yet meet with opposition and obstruction; but if he cherish an apprehensive caution, there will be good fortune:' – a strong (line) has come and got the central place (in the lower trigram).'If he must prosecute the contention to the (bitter) end, there will be evil:' – contention is not a thing to be carried on to extremity. 'It will be advantageous to meet with the great man:' – what he sets a value on is the due mean, and the correct place. 'It will not be advantageous to cross the great stream:' – one (attempting to do so) would find himself in an abyss.

(The trigram representing) heaven and (that representing) water, moving away from each other, form Sòng. The superior man, in accordance with this, in the transaction of affairs takes good counsel about his first steps.
1: The first SIX, divided, shows its subject not perpetuating the matter about which (the contention is). He will suffer the small (injury) of being spoken against, but the end will be fortunate.
'He does not perpetuate the matter about which (the contention is):' – contention should not be prolonged. Although 'he may suffer the small (injury) of being spoken against,' his argument is clear.
2: The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject unequal to the contention. If he retire and keep concealed (where) the inhabitants of his city are (only) three hundred families, he will fall into no mistake.

'He is unequal to the contention; he retires and keeps concealed, stealthily withdrawing from it:' – for him from his lower place to contend with (the stronger one) above, would be to (invite) calamity, as if he brought it with his hand to himself.
3: The third SIX, divided, shows its subject keeping in the old place assigned for his support, and firmly correct. Perilous as the position is, there will be good fortune in the end. Should he perchance engage in the king's business, he will not (claim the merit of) achievement.
'He confines himself to the support assigned to him of old:' – (thus) following those above him, he will have good fortune.
4: The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject unequal to the contention. He returns to (the study of Heaven's) ordinances, changes (his wish to contend), and rests in being firm and correct. There will be good fortune.
'He returns to (the study of Heaven's) ordinances, changes (his wish to contend), and rests in being firm and correct:' – he does not fail (in doing what is right).
5: S. The fifth NINE, undivided, shows its subject contending – and with great good fortune.
'He contends; – and 'with great fortune: – this is shown by his holding the due mean and being in the correct place.
6: The topmost NINE, undivided, shows how its subject may have the leathern belt conferred on him (by the sovereign), and thrice it shall be taken from him in a morning.
'He receives the robe through his contention:' – but still be is not deserving of respect.

main: Shī indicates how, in the case which it supposes, with firmness and correctness, and (a leader of) age and experience, there will be good fortune and no error.

(The name) Shī describes the multitude (of the host). The 'firmness and correctness' (which the hexagram indicates) refer to (moral) correctness (of aim). When (the mover) is able to use the multitude with such correctness, he may attain to the royal sway. There is (the symbol of) strength in the centre (of the trigram below), and it is responded to (by its proper correlate above). The action gives rise to perils, but is in accordance (with the best sentiments of men). (Its mover) may by such action distress all the country, but the people will follow him; – there will be good fortune, and what error should there be?

(The trigram representing) the earth and in the midst of it that representing water, form Shī. The superior man, in accordance with this, nourishes and educates the people, and collects (from among them) the multitudes (of the hosts).
1: The first SIX, divided, shows the host going forth according to the rules (for such a movement). If these be not good, there will be evil.
'The host goes forth according to the rules (for) such a movement:' – if those rules be not observed, there will be evil.
2: The second NINE, undivided, shows (the leader) in the midst of the host. There will be good fortune and no error. The king has thrice conveyed to him the orders (of his favour).

'He is in the midst of the host, and there will be good fortune:' – he has received the favour of Heaven. 'The king has thrice conveyed to him the orders (of) his favour:' – (the king) cherishes the myriad regions in his heart.
3: The third SIX, divided, shows how the host may, possibly, have many inefficient leaders. There will be evil.
'The host with the possibility of its having many idle leaders:' – great will be its want of success.
4: The fourth SIX, divided, shows the host in retreat. There is no error.
'The host is in retreat; but there is no error:' – there has been no failure in the regular course.
5: The fifth SIX, divided, shows birds in the fields, which it will be advantageous to seize (and destroy). In that case there will be no error. If the oldest son leads the host, and younger men (idly occupy offices assigned to them), however firm and correct he may be, there will be evil.

'The oldest son leads the host:' – its movements are directed by him in accordance with his position in the centre. 'Younger men idly occupy their positions:' – the employment of such men is improper.
6: The topmost SIX, divided, shows the great ruler delivering his charges, (appointing some) to be rulers of states, and others to undertake the headship of clans; but small men should not be employed (in such positions).
'The great ruler delivers his charges:' – thereby he rightly apportions merit. 'Small men should not be employed:' – they are sure to throw the states into confusion.

main: Bǐ indicates that (under the conditions which it supposes) there is good fortune. But let (the principal party intended in it) re-examine himself, (as if) by divination, whether his virtue be great, unintermitting, and firm. If it be so, there will be no error. Those who have not rest will then come to him; and with those who are (too) late in coming it will be ill.

'Bǐ indicates that there is good fortune:' – (the name) Bǐ denotes help; (and we see in the figure) inferiors docilely following (their superior). 'Let (the principal party intended in it) reexamine himself, (as if) by divination, whether his virtue be great, unintermitting, and firm; – if it be so, there will be no error: – all this follows from the position of the strong line in the centre (of the upper trigram). 'Those who have not rest will come to him:' – high and low will respond to its subject. 'With those who are (too) late in coming it will be ill:' – (for them) the way (of good fortune here indicated) has been exhausted.

(The trigram representing) the earth, and over it (that representing) water, form Bǐ. The ancient kings, in accordance with this, established the various states and maintained an affectionate relation to their princes.
1: The first SIX, divided, shows its subject seeking by his sincerity to win the attachment of his object. There will be no error. Let (the breast) be full of sincerity as an earthenware vessel is of its contents, and it will in the end bring other advantages.
From 'the seeking union with its object' shown in the first SIX, (divided),there will be other advantages.
2: In the second SIX, divided, we see the movement towards union and attachment proceeding from the inward (mind). With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
'The movement towards union and attachment proceeds from the inward (mind):' – (the party concerned) does not fail in what is proper to himself
3: In the third SIX, divided, we see its subject seeking for union with such as ought not to be associated with.
'Union is sought with such as ought not to be associated with:' – but will not injury be the result?
4: In the fourth SIX, divided, we see its subject seeking for union with the one beyond himself. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
'Union is sought (by the party intended here) with one beyond himself, and (in this case) with a worthy object:' – he is following (the ruler) above him.
5: The fifth NINE, undivided, affords the most illustrious instance of seeking union and attachment. (We seem to see in it) the king urging his pursuit of the game (only) in three directions, and allowing the escape of all the animals before him, while the people of his towns do not warn one another (to prevent it). There will be good fortune.

'The good fortune belonging to the most illustrious instance of seeking union and attachment' appears in the correct and central position (of the fifth line, undivided). (The king's) neglecting (the animals) confronting him (and then fleeing), and (only) taking those who present themselves as it were obediently, is seen in his allowing the escape of those in front of him.' 'That the people of his towns do not warn one another (to prevent such escape),' shows how he, in his high eminence, has made them pursue the due course.
6: In the topmost SIX, divided, we see one seeking union and attachment without having taken the first step (to such an end). There will be evil.
'He seeks union and attachment without taking the first (step to such an end):' – there is no possibility of a (good) issue.

main: Xiǎo Xù indicates that (under its conditions) there will be progress and success. (We see) dense clouds, but no rain coming from our borders in the west.

In Xiǎo Xù the weak line occupies its (proper) position, and (the lines) above and below respond to it. Hence comes the name of Xiǎo Xù (Small Restraint). (It presents the symbols of) strength and flexibility. Strong lines are in the central places, and the will (of their subjects) will have free course. Thus it indicates that there will be progress and success. 'Dense clouds but no rain' indicate the movement (of the strong lines) still going forward. The 'Commencing at our western border' indicates that the (beneficial) influence has not yet been widely displayed.
(The trigram representing) the sky, and that representing wind moving above it, form Xiǎo Xù The superior man, in accordance with this, adorns the outward manifestation of his virtue.
1: The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject returning and pursuing his own course. What mistake should he fall into? There will be good fortune.
'He returns and pursues his own path:' – it is right that there should be good fortune.
2: The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject, by the attraction (of the former line), returning (to the proper course). There will be good fortune.
'By the attraction (of the subject of the former line) he returns (to its own course),' and is in the central place: – neither will he err in what is due from him.
3: The third NINE, undivided, suggests the idea of a carriage, the strap beneath which has been removed, or of a husband and wife looking on each other with averted eyes.
'Husband and wife look on each other with averted eyes:' – (the subject of line three is like a husband who) cannot maintain correctly his relations with his wife.
4: The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject possessed of sincerity. The danger of bloodshed is thereby averted, and his (ground for) apprehension dismissed. There will be no mistake.
'He is possessed of sincerity; his (ground for) apprehension is dismissed:' – (the subjects of the lines) above agree in aim with him.
5: The fifth NINE, undivided, shows its subject possessed of sincerity, and drawing others to unite with him. Rich in resources, he employs his neighbours (in the same cause with himself).
'He is possessed of sincerity, and draws others to unite with him:' – he does not use only his own rich resources.
6: The topmost NINE, undivided, shows how the rain has fallen, and the (onward progress) is stayed – (so) must we value the full accumulation of the virtue (represented by the upper trigram). But a wife (exercising restraint), however firm and correct she may be, is in a position of peril, (and like) the moon approaching to the full. If the superior man prosecute his measures (in such circumstances), there will be evil.

'The rain has fallen and (the onward progress) is stayed:' – the power (denoted in the figure) has accumulated to the full. 'If the superior man prosecute his measures, there will be evil:' – he will find himself obstructed.

main: (Lǚ suggests the idea of) one treading on the tail of a tiger, which does not bite him. There will be progress and success.

In Lǚ we have (the symbol of) weakness treading on (that of) strength. (The lower trigram) indicates pleasure and satisfaction, and responds to (the upper) indicating strength. Hence (it is said), 'He treads on the tail of a tiger, which does not bite him; there will be progress and success.' (The fifth line is) strong, in the centre, and in its correct place. (Its subject) occupies the God-(given) position, and falls into no distress or failure; – (his) action will be brilliant.

(The trigram representing) the sky above, and below it (that representing the waters of) a marsh, form Lǚ. The superior man, in accordance with this, discriminates between high and low, and gives settlement to the aims of the people.
1: The first NINE, undivided, shows its subject treading his accustomed path. If he go forward, there will be no error.
'He treads his accustomed path and goes forward:' – singly and exclusively he carries out his (long-cherished) wishes.
2: The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject treading the path that is level and easy – a quiet and solitary man, to whom, if he be firm and correct, there will be good fortune.
'A quiet and solitary man, to whom, being firm and correct, there will be good fortune:' – holding the due mean, he will not allow himself to be thrown into disorder.
3: The third SIX, divided, shows a one-eyed man (who thinks he) can see; a lame man (who thinks he) can walk well; one who treads on the tail of a tiger and is bitten. (All this indicates) ill fortune. We have a (mere) bravo acting the part of a great ruler.

'A one-eyed man (who thinks that he) can see:' – he is not fit to see clearly. 'A lame man (who thinks that he can) tread well:' – one cannot walk along with him. 'The ill fortune of being bitten' arises from the place not being the proper one for him. 'A (mere) bravo acting the part of a great ruler:' – this is owing to his aims being (too) violent.
4: The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject treading on the tail of a tiger. He becomes full of apprehensive caution, and in the end there will be good fortune.
'He becomes full of apprehensive caution, and in the end there will be good fortune:' – his aim takes effect.
5: The fifth NINE, undivided, shows the resolute tread of its subject. Though he be firm and correct, there will be peril.
'He treads resolutely; and though he be firm and correct, there is peril:' – this is due to his being in the position that is correct and appropriate to him.
6: The sixth NINE, undivided, tells us to look at (the whole course) that is trodden, and examine the presage which that gives. If it be complete and without failure, there will be great good fortune.
'There will be great good fortune,' and that in the occupancy of the topmost line: – this is great matter for congratulation.

main: In Tài (we see) the little gone and the great come. (It indicates that) there will be good fortune, with progress and success.

'The little come and the great gone in Tài, and its indication that there will be good fortune with progress and success' show to us heaven and earth in communication with each other, and all things in consequence having free course, and (also) the high and the low, (superiors and inferiors), in communication with one another, and possessed by the same aim. The inner (trigram) is made up of the strong and undivided lines, and the outer of the weak and divided; the inner is (the symbol of) strength, and the outer of docility; the inner (represents) the superior man, and the outer the small man. (Thus) the way of the superior man appears increasing, and that of the small man decreasing.

(The trigrams for) heaven and earth in communication together form Tài. The (sage) sovereign, in harmony with this, fashions and completes (his regulations) after the courses of heaven and earth, and assists the application of the adaptations furnished by them, – in order to benefit the people.
1: The first NINE, undivided, suggests the idea of grass pulled up, and bringing with it other stalks with whose roots it is connected. Advance (on the part of its subject) will be fortunate.
'The good fortune of advance, (as suggested by the emblem of) the grass pulled up,' arises from the will (of the party intended) being set on what is external to himself.
2: The second NINE, undivided, shows one who can bear with the uncultivated, will cross the He without a boat, does not forget the distant, and has no (selfish) friendships. Thus does he prove himself acting in accordance with the course of the due Mean.
'He bears with the uncultivated, and proves himself acting in accordance with the due mean:' – for (his intelligence is) bright and (his capacity is) great.
3: The third NINE, undivided, shows that, while there is no state of peace that is not liable to be disturbed, and no departure (of evil men) so that they shall not return, yet when one is firm and correct, as he realises the distresses that may arise, he will commit no error. There is no occasion for sadness at the certainty (of such recurring changes); and in this mood the happiness (of the present) may be (long) enjoyed.
'There is no going away so that there shall not be a return' refers to this as the point where the interaction of heaven and earth takes place.
4: The fourth SIX, divided, shows its subject fluttering (down) – not relying on his own rich resources, but calling in his neighbours. (They all come) not as having received warning, but in the sincerity (of their hearts).

'He comes fluttering (down), not relying on his own rich resources:' – both he and his neighbours are out of their real (place where they are). 'They have not received warning, but (come) in the sincerity (of their hearts):' – this is what they have desired in the core of their hearts.
5: The fifth six, divided, reminds us of (king) Di-yi's (rule about the) marriage of his younger sister. By such a course there is happiness and there will be great good fortune.
'By such a course there is happiness, and there will be great good fortune:' – (the subject of the line) employs the virtue proper to his central position to carry his wishes into effect.
6: The sixth six, divided, shows us the city wall returned into the moat. It is not the time to use the army. (The subject of the line) may, indeed, announce his orders to the people of his own city; but however correct and firm he may be, he will have cause for regret.
'The city wall returned back into the moat' shows how the (governmental) orders have (long) been in disorder.

main: In Pǐ there is the want of good understanding between the (different classes of) men, and its indication is unfavourable to the firm and correct course of the superior man. We see in it the great gone and the little come.
